message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aspirin overdose can cause respiratory alkalosis as the patient tries to compensate for the metabolic acidosis caused by the aspirin. However, eventually, anion gap metabolic acidosis will develop as the aspirin is metabolized to salicylic acid. But the onset of respiratory alkalosis is the first acid/base change to occur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aspirin overdose causes hyperventilation, leading to respiratory alkalosis as the first acid/base change. Later on, if the overdose is severe, it can cause metabolic acidosis, but respiratory alkalosis is the initial change.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aspirin overdose can cause hyperventilation, leading to respiratory alkalosis as the first acid/base change. Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis may occur later due to accumulation of acidic metabolites, but it is not the first change. Anion gap metabolic acidosis and metabolic alkalosis are not expected in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aspirin overdose leads to respiratory alkalosis due to hyperventilation as a compensatory mechanism. This occurs before the onset of metabolic acidosis which is caused by an accumulation of acid products from aspirin metabolism. Therefore, option (D) respiratory alkalosis is the correct answer.

We refer to the basic principles of acid-base balance. Aspirin overdose can cause hyperventilation and therefore respiratory alkalosis, which would be the first acid-base change to occur. Anion gap metabolic acidosis can occur later as the body tries to compensate for the respiratory alkalosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Overdose of aspirin can cause hyperventilation, which leads to respiratory alkalosis, as the first acid/base change in this patient. It may later progress to a mixed acid-base disorder, including metabolic acidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aspirin overdose causes respiratory alkalosis, which occurs as a result of hyperventilation caused by stimulation of the respiratory center in the brain in response to elevated carbon dioxide levels. Other acid/base imbalances may occur later, but respiratory alkalosis is the first to occur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aspirin overdose causes hyperventilation, resulting in respiratory alkalosis as the first acid/base disturbance. Aspirin overdose can also cause metabolic acidosis, but this occurs later as the aspirin is metabolized into salicylic acid. Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis and metabolic alkalosis are not associated with aspirin overdose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Overdose with aspirin can cause hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis as the first acid/base change. Other acid/base changes, such as metabolic acidosis, may occur later as the aspirin is metabolized.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Aspirin toxicity can cause respiratory alkalosis due to increased respiratory rate as a compensatory mechanism. Other acid/base imbalances may occur later on, but respiratory alkalosis will occur first in this patient.
